formattedAddress: 167 Avenue A, New York, NY 10009, USA
adrFormatAddress: 167 Avenue A, New York, NY 10009, USA

editorialSummary.text: Restaurant devoted to sisig (with fried pork or variations) & other Filipino specialties.

originalText.text:
I had some of the best pork dishes here. I think about the pork sig sig almost daily. This dish had a nice spice to it and the crispy bits of pork just had amazing texture as I chewed. You have to pair this with the garlic rice! I also enjoyed the Pork Kare Kare, the sauce wasn’t too sweet and the pork was still crispy. I should also mention the Beef Salpicao which was very tasty. We paired this all with the garlic rice and it was amazing.
The service was also good here and the restaurant is a nice vibe. The end it off, we got our hands on the Halo Halo and it was also a Burt of flavor and textures. I would recommend you try this since it’s filled with so many toppings like Bean/jelly/ice cream. It’s a huge portion too!
I would reccomend this for first times who want to try Filipino food!
I have to come back to try the Pork Adobo

originalText.text: Probably the best Filipino food in NYC. I tried the crispy pork sisig with garlic rice. This dish was a culinary masterpiece, perfectly capturing the essence of Filipino cuisine with the crispy pork offering a satisfying texture with every bite. Quality of the food was top notch. Highly recommend Mama Finas

text.text: Probably the best Filipino food in NYC. I tried the crispy pork sisig with garlic rice. This dish was a culinary masterpiece, perfectly capturing the essence of Filipino cuisine with the crispy pork offering a satisfying texture with every bite. Quality of the food was top notch. Highly recommend Mama Finas

originalText.text: I had never tried Filipino food before, so I came here with a Filipino friend and we shared the pork sisig and pork adobo. The dishes were absolutely addictive - the adobo sauce was so flavorful that I could drink it by itself, and the sisig was so crispy and oily, it went great with the rice. The portions are quite big and filling, but both my friend and I were super hungry so we ended up finishing them. We also stayed afterwards.to keep talking and the staff was super understanding!

text.text: I had never tried Filipino food before, so I came here with a Filipino friend and we shared the pork sisig and pork adobo. The dishes were absolutely addictive - the adobo sauce was so flavorful that I could drink it by itself, and the sisig was so crispy and oily, it went great with the rice. The portions are quite big and filling, but both my friend and I were super hungry so we ended up finishing them. We also stayed afterwards.to keep talking and the staff was super understanding!

originalText.text:
Was with a group, and the only vegetarian.

They were not only out of the main veggie entree (tofu sisig), but also ran out of any veggie sides except some beans. They improvised with fried eggs, with some cajoling.

Some of my friends had reported that the dishes came out of order. Servers were generally polite.

To add insult to injury, they charged us for the items they had run out of, and refused to make good on the check.

Atmosphere in the restaurant was pleasant.

Will not be going back though.

originalText.text: Went here for dinner with a bunch of friends, had the boodle fight. They lay out all the food on banana leaves and you eat with your hands. Everything was delicious, we upgraded the meal with garlic rice. Lechon came with both lechon sauce and vinegar. We opted for the squid sisig since we already had beef, pork and shrimp. The BBQ sticks were really good too. We had a vegan with us, they made her tofu sisig and some string beans. The tofu was pretty good and even had some kick to it with the peppers they used. For dessert we had leche flan, it was nice and dense like traditional filipino flan and had a good caramel sauce on it. If you are looking for a good filipino restaurant in the city you should really check it out.
